Ptosis (drooping eyelids) and diplopia (double vision) are common symptoms of myasthenia gravis.

Rationale:
Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness of the skeletal muscles. It is caused by autoantibodies that block or destroy acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. The weakness is often worse at the end of the day because it takes more time for the acetylcholine receptors to be depleted. Ptosis (drooping eyelids) and diplopia (double vision) are common symptoms of myasthenia gravis.
